summary: Learn how to build a Model Context Protocol (MCP) server with PostgreSQL integration. MCP servers let you connect custom data sources and make them available for use inside Cursor.
key_takeaways: MCP servers connect Cursor to external tools like databases for querying and schema inspection.
Use the @modelcontextprotocol/sdk package to implement MCP servers.
Test MCP servers with the MCP Inspector before connecting to Cursor.
Deploy as HTTP service for shared team access instead of local stdio.

questions.question: What npm package is used to build MCP servers?
questions.explanation: The @modelcontextprotocol/sdk package is used along with zod for schema definitions. Install with 'bun add postgres @modelcontextprotocol/sdk zod'.

questions.question: What tool can you use to test an MCP server before connecting it to Cursor?
questions.explanation: Use the MCP Inspector ('npx @modelcontextprotocol/inspector bun run index.ts') to see what the server exposes and verify that tools and resources behave as expected.

questions.question: Why would you deploy an MCP server as an HTTP service instead of using stdio?

options.text: To enable shared database access across multiple team members
HTTP is the only production-ready option

questions.explanation: Deploying as HTTP enables shared database access, centralized configuration, enhanced security with authentication and rate limiting, and observability across the team.
